I've used it and made decent gains on it. The only things I don't like so much are that I don't recover well on just 1 day of rest, especially if I really try to push progression. Also, the way it's designed you are very pre-exhausted by the time you hit your final isolations, which is fine, but it never really allows you to get much stronger on them either. So personally I condensed this into a 4 day U/L with an arm day or 5 day U/L/U/L/U. That way I have the same frequency, hit all muscles just as often in a week and get more rest and if I want I can go heavier on the arm day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I am fat. I am disgustingly fat. I am the fattest human I know. I have nothing but excess poundage all over my body. My fingers are fat. My wrists are fat. My eyes are fat. (Can you imagine fat eyes?) I am hundreds of pounds overweight. Flesh drips from me like hot fudge off a sundae. My girth has been an object of disbelief to everyone who’s seen me. There is no question about it, I’m a regular fatty. Now, the reader may ask, are there advantages or disadvantages to being built like a planet? I do not mean to be facetious or speak in paradoxes, but I must answer that fat in itself is above bourgeois morality. It is simply fat. That fat could have a value of its own, that fat could be, say, evil or pitying, is, of course, a joke. Absurd! For what is fat after all but an accumulation of pounds? And what are pounds? Simply an aggregate composite of cells. Can a cell be moral? Is a cell beyond good or evil? Who knows—they’re so small. No, my friend, we must never attempt to distinguish between good fat and bad fat. We must train ourselves to confront the obese without judging, without thinking this man’s fat is first-rate fat and this poor wretch’s is grubby fat.

Take the case of Kek. This fellow was porcine to such a degree that he could not fit through the average doorframe without the aid of a crowbar. Indeed, Kek would not think to pass from room to room in a conventional dwelling without first stripping completely and then buttering himself. I am no stranger to the insults Kek must have borne from passing gangs of young rowdies. How frequently he must have been stung by cries of “Tubby!” and “Blimp!” How it must have hurt when the governor of the province turned to him on the Eve of Michaelmas and said, before many dignitaries, “You hulking pot of kasha!”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Then one day, when Kek could stand it no longer, he dieted. Yes, dieted! First sweets went. Then bread, alcohol, starches, sauces. In short, Kek gave up the very stuff that makes a man unable to tie his shoelaces without help from the Santini Brothers. Gradually he began to slim down. Rolls of flesh fell from his arms and legs. Where once he looked roly-poly, he suddenly appeared in public with a normal build. Yes, even an attractive build. He seemed the happiest of men. I say “seemed,” for eighteen years later, when he was near death and fever raged throughout his slender frame, he was heard to cry out, “My fat! Bring me my fat! Oh, please! I must have my fat! Oh, somebody lay some avoirdupois on me! What a fool I’ve been. To part with one’s fat! I must have been in league with the Devil!” I think that the point of the story is obvious.

Now the reader is probably thinking, Why, then, if you are Lard City, have you not joined a circus? Because— and I confess this with no small embarrassment—I cannot leave the house. I cannot go out because I cannot get my pants on. My legs are too thick to dress. They are the living result of more corned beef than there is on Second Avenue—I would say about twelve thousand sandwiches per leg. And not all lean, even though I specified. One thing is certain: If my fat could speak, it would probably speak of a man’s intense loneliness— with, oh, perhaps a few additional pointers on how to make a sailboat out of paper. Every pound on my body wants to be heard from, as do Chins Four through Twelve inclusive. My fat is strange fat. It has seen much. My calves alone have lived a lifetime. Mine is not happy fat, but it is real fat. It is not fake fat. Fake fat is the worst fat you can have, although I don’t know if the stores still carry it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
But let me tell you how it was that I became fat. For I was not always fat. It is the Church that has made me thus. At one time I was thin—quite thin. So thin, in fact, that to call me fat would have been an error in perception. I remained thin until one day—I think it was my twentieth birthday—when I was having tea and cracknels with my uncle at a fine restaurant. Suddenly my uncle put a question to me. “Do you believe in God?” he asked. “And if so, what do you think He weighs?” So saying, he took a long and luxurious draw at his cigar and, in that confident, assured manner he has cultivated, lapsed into a coughing fit so violent I thought he would hemorrhage.

“I do not believe in God,” I told him. “For if there is a God, then tell me, Uncle, why is there poverty and baldness? Why do some men go through life immune to a thousand mortal enemies of the race, while others get a migraine that lasts for weeks? Why are our days numbered and not, say, lettered? Answer me, Uncle. Or have I shocked you?”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I knew I was safe in saying this, because nothing ever shocked the man. Indeed, he had seen his chess tutor’s mother raped by Turks and would have found the whole incident amusing had it not taken so much time.

“Good nephew,” he said, “there is a God, despite what you think, and He is everywhere. Yes? Everywhere!”

“Everywhere, Uncle? How can you say that when you don’t even know for sure if we exist? True, I am touching your wart at this moment, but could that not be an illusion? Could not all life be an illusion? Indeed, are there not certain sects of holy men in the East who are convinced that nothing exists outside their minds except for the Oyster Bar at Grand Central Station? Could it not be simply that we are alone and aimless, doomed to wander in an indifferent universe, with no hope of salvation, nor any prospect except misery, death, and the empty reality of eternal nothing?”

I could see that I made a deep impression on my uncle with this, for he said to me, “You wonder why you’re not invited to more parties! Jesus, you’re morbid!” He accused me of being nihilistic and then said, in that cryptic way the senile have, “God is not always where one seeks Him, but I assure you, dear nephew, He is everywhere. In these cracknels, for instance.” With that, he departed, leaving me his blessing and a check that read like the tab for an aircraft carrier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I returned home wondering what it was he meant by that one simple statement “He is everywhere. In these cracknels, for instance.” Drowsy by then, and out of sorts, I lay down on my bed and took a brief nap. In that time, I had a dream that was to change my life forever. In the dream, I am strolling in the country, when I suddenly notice I am hungry. Starved, if you will. I come upon a restaurant and I enter. I order the open-hot-roast-beef sandwich and a side of French. The waitress, who resembles my landlady (a thoroughly insipid woman who reminds one instantly of some of the hairier lichens), tries to tempt me into ordering the chicken salad, which doesn’t look fresh. As I am conversing with this woman, she turns into a twenty-four-piece starter set of silverware. I become hysterical with laughter, which suddenly turns to tears and then into a serious ear infection. The room is suffused with a radiant glow, and I see a shimmering figure approach on a white steed. It is my podiatrist, and I fall to the ground with guilt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Such was my dream. I awoke with a tremendous sense of well- being. Suddenly I was optimistic. Everything was clear. My uncle’s statement reverberated to the core of my very existence. I went to the kitchen and started to eat. I ate everything in sight. Cakes, breads, cereals, meat, fruits. Succulent chocolates, vegetables in sauce, wines, fish, creams and noodles, eclairs, and wursts totalling in excess of sixty thousand dollars. If God is everywhere, I had concluded, then He is in food. Therefore, the more I ate the godlier I would become. Impelled by this new religious fervor, I glutted myself like a fanatic. In six months, I was the holiest of holies, with a heart entirely devoted to my prayers and a stomach that crossed the state line by itself. I last saw my feet one Thursday morning in Vitebsk, although for all I know they are still down there. I ate and ate and grew and grew. To reduce would have been the greatest folly. Even a sin! For when we lose twenty pounds, dear reader (and I am assuming you are not as large as I), we may be losing the twenty best pounds we have! We may be losing the pounds that contain our genius, our humanity, our love and honesty or, in the case of one inspector general I knew, just some unsightly flab around the hips.

Fat is everything! Unless, of course, you’re overweight.

There's a few things I would mention.

1. Age
For myself, I became more confident and self-assured as I grew older. Especially under 25, most people still have a ways to go in becoming a fully mature adult.

2. Get out of your comfort zone
I don't mean just go to the gym and work hard, or don't play video games or some shit. If you really get out of your comfort zone, it will change you. Big experiences that force you to re-evaluate your life and who you are will begin to change the way that you interact with others and the way you feel about yourself. I suppose lots of people do this through travel, seeking out new experiences, martial arts, volunteering etc.

3. Know your shit
When it comes to a specific circumstance. Say you're a paramedic or a firefighter - if you're brand new, you're probably not going to be very confident when you go to a really difficult emergency. But, if you've studied a lot, you know a lot, and have plenty of experience you will be less fazed and more able to just act - it hasn't got much to do with being a confident person, that's more to do with just knowing what needs to be done at that time, and thus being able to direct other people simply because you have good suggestions.


A couple other things I would mention are:
-If you're not very social, being more social and interacting with lots of different people from all walks of life will help you.
-Be careful not to mistake some things for being confident. If you punch someone in the head for some reason, you might feel like a badass momentarily - but you may have unwittingly done it out of insecurity. In fact, I'd guess a lot of people who take lots of risks and get in fights are often insecure. So it's good to check your intentions and reflect on shit.

Count calories and eat at a deficit.
>How do I build muscle?
Start lifting weights or calisthenics, consider bulking.

Numbers refer to amount of 45lb/20kg weights on each side of a standard barbell and their respective lifts. 135 lb OHP/225 Bench Press/315 Squat/405 Deadlift.

Beginners should at-least attempt to stick to a standard routine before attempting to make their own.

Most things are good in moderation. Just read the nutrition facts.

10 reps on compounds is retarded. Do 3x5 for all but deadlifts and do a working set of 1x5 for that instead. Ideally you want the weight to be heavy enough that finishing all 3 sets to be tough. >continue using 20lbs as your primary weight until you reach 15-20 reps. This is a perfectly fine rep range for curls and once you hit it you should be able to do 8-10 reps with 25
>swap it out for a different exercise for a little while to increase your bicep strength and come back to it
>>69471551
It varies so much based on the individual that you'll just need to experiment with different foods, quantities and meal timing until you find what works for you.

>>69469880
>ffs so is 3x10 good enough for hypertrophy? i’m reading sources that say 10-20 sets per exercise per week is optimal for muscle growth.

It's closer to 20 sets per muscle, which is easy to do with 3x10 if you do more than one lift per muscle, which you should.
Another muh optimizashun thing is to hit the same muscle across two workouts no more than 48 hours apart and then give it time to recover.

What this anon said is pretty much correct >>69470899 >>69470932. The hyper trophy range, and it's a soft range, is like 8 to 20+, but the idea is that you are really close to or failing at the top of your desired rep count.
For example, I really like x10 sets, it feels good for me, so any time I am physically able to reach 12 reps, I up the weight or slow down the eccentric.

Lifting is not rocket surgery, stop listening to basedence lifting youtubers and just make sure you're lifting at least 3 to 4 times a week and that you're progressing.

posts.com:
Encourage one another and build each other up edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For insatiably gluttonous golems who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

Previous Thread: >>69455752

>>69471943
Well, you did plateau. As you lose weight and reduce your calories, your body will become more efficient with the calories you are providing it as a survival mechanism.

I think at least maintaining for a few weeks could help and see if you can increase your maintenance calories as you build muscle. At around the 150-170 range you should be able to show quite a bit of muscle. I'm sure it would be nice for you to hit your 155 goal, but fitness goals require levels of sacrifice, and getting to 155 may be a sacrifice you are unwilling to make. You did a large amount of the work losing 50 lbs, it would be wise to see if you can at least maintain that loss going forward. If you incrementally lose weight from now on, it'll require less of a drastic intervention and as long as you're trending in the right direction, you'll reach your goals. It's actually quite easy to lose large amounts of weight if you have the willpower, where people tend to fail is the long term weight loss and that's due to making the mistake of losing too much too fast.

The institute of human anatomy recently did a decent video on cardio and fat loss.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69472036
>What I'm saying though.. is that we've already been taught most of the lessons we need to know.
If you have attended a lesson, but did not learn from it, do you really know it?
If you knew how to do these things, or if you knew what actually was best for you, wouldn't you already be doing them?
Or do you think you know what is best for you, but your idea is unrealistic and removed from reality, expecting you to have a sense of discipline you haven't displayed even once in your life before?

What you believe is that you know what is best for you and all you are missing is some additional secret that will allow you to implement this knowledge in your life. All I can tell you is that this additional secret does not exist and the reason you do not know it is because what you think is best for you is not actually best for you, it is a unrealistic daydream, filled with the external values and disregarding your own nature. I really wish I could formulate this knowledge better, because I see my younger self in what I read, but some lessons are very hard to learn without some specific experience.
My best advice I can give you is twofold:
* The human spirit is deep and complex and we understand very little of it. There are almost always reasons for why we do the things we do and why we don't do the things we think we ought to do. Investigate these reasons and maybe you will find a solution that allows you to flip your switch. My guess is it will instead lead you to understanding my point about unlearned lessons and the nonexistence of the switch.
* No matter if I am right or wrong, until you did not find the switch, just get started small. You can do both after all. This way if the switch turns out to be a lie, you will thank me for less wasted time.
Good luck out there anon. You will learn these lessons eventually, the only question is when. I'm rooting for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
After years of bad sleep, months of looking for solutions and countless threads, here are the best solutions ive found, ranked from least to most helpful. Hopefully it could help other anons on here.

>Place phone away from bed so that (a) wont get the urge to use it before bed and (b) have to get up to turn off the alarm
>Cool down the room before sleeping. Better to have it too cold and use an extra blanket than have it be too hot and not let you sleep.
>Only use the bed when its time to sleep so that your brain knows it time to sleep. No reading/working/playing vidya or browsing /fit/ in bed. Sounds dumb but it really works.
>10 mins meditation if and when youre stressed or have racing thoughts.
>the one that helped the most was mouth taping. Been snoring since i was 16 and tried everything short of buying a CPAP (snoring strips, silicone vents, etc.). Yes its a tiktok trend but it works. (dont buy overpriced special tape for it, get some surgical tape and put it vertically over your mouth) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f3jjRdvKY54

Here is some other stuff that is common sense and well known. Make sure to do all of these before trying the above.

>Consistent wakeup and bedtime
>Limit screen time 1-2h before bed
>Avoid coffee in the evening
>Make sure your room is dark and quiet (blackout curtains if needed)

You gas them with CO2 (mice and rats don't have the pain receptors we do so they just go to sleep) then, for my work, I would perfused the mice (cut their chest open, make two cuts in their heart and pump saline into one side to flush all of the blood out of their circulatory system) then cut across their abdomen and pull on the fat pads attached to their reproductive system. I didn't do much with the testis but instead would take the epididymis, section it into the three segments then you just slice those up and tease them apart with teasers in a solution and bam you have sperm.

I never really looked at the sperm samples - I mainly just spun them down then extracted all of their genetic material to do large scale miRNA analyses.

Nothing sticks with you like the smell of a pool of blood from 9 mice in the morning.

hey anon, still hanging in there? ive done 5 day fasts so here are my tips

1) when you're about to fail - distract yourself, just like you did with this thread
2) shorten your time horizon: "i just gotta get through the next hour, then its almost time to XYZ and after that it'll be evening and then I'll just go to sleep early".
3) negotiate with yourself: " ok i'll fast for half a day more and if it's REALLY unbearable then i'll call it quits". But don't sabotage yourself by buying food upfront and "plan to fail".
4) find rewards to give yourself for each additional day you succeed. could be a trip to the zoo, could be shopping for some cool sport-related item

also remember:
day 2 is when your body finishes up with eating the glycogen and switches to using your fat as fuel. don't quit when the fun has just started!!!
day 3 is reportedly the worst/hardest day for anyone fasting. After that you can fast indefinitely.

Lastly: if you give up early, don't worry! Fasting gets easier with practice. Treat you " failure" as practice and go do another attempt.

I had only 13 inch arms after training for a couple of years & being able to do 5 chinups with 40kg on the weight belt. Now they're 15 inches. Still not properly big but there's a saying about listening to someone with poor genetics for a body part who built it up despite the odds, over a genetically gifted person who built that bodypart with ease.
Isolate the muscle. Particularly with an exercise where you can really feel the muscle shorten & lengthen. Going kinda slowly helps, nothing crazy, two seconds up two seconds down. 40 seconds of nonstop contraction should be a pretty regular occurrence. Go to failure. Two exercises for bis & two for Tris should be enough. Supinated bicep curl, hammer grip curl, overhead extension & a pushdown should do the job. Pick exercises where the sticking point is in the middle, those are generally the most effective builders.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
List of things that worked best for me:
>light weight + extremely slow eccentric
>keeping tension on the biceps at all times / cable curls
>loading dumbbells unevenly (more focus on rotation of wrist and different resistance at different points)
>anything that forces the biceps to also stabilize: dangling weight from a bar, using fixed weight ez curl bars or 5' straight bars with one hand
I find that the latter is particularly effective because you can get stronger peak contractions + you get involuntary contractions on top of that

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69471444

It hits the outer muscle in your forearm (brachioradialis) & the outer head of the bicep (brachialis) about equally. However hammer curls are a good 'weak forearm' test. If you've never done them you might feel it more in the outer part of your forearm than in the outer part of your bicep, but that's just an indication of an underdeveloped brachioradialis. If you actually do them regularly then they'll stimulate the shit out of both your outer forearm & outer bicep.

The dopamine boosts you get makes your neurological circuits so that you enjoy gaming more and all other things less. The anxiety kicks in as one of the earlier symptoms.

Idk, it depends. If she's e.g. squatting >1pl8 you could compliment her on the weight, saying it's pretty impressive and then ask her how long she's been training.
If she has particularly good form, you could compliment her on that and then say e.g. you wish you had better mobility or something.
If it's the end of your session and you're both leaving at the same time you could ask her how her workout was, and perhaps say something related to how often you see her, e.g. "I don't see you here much" or "I've seen you around quite a lot," or "do you come here often?" etc. depending on the which one makes sense to say.
If she's doing bench press, you could also offer to give a spot.
I don't think the opening line is that important, it's just a jumping off point, but it's just daunting to make that move.

>>69471500
whatever exercises you can do

You can google / youtube exercises for knee injuries for your affected limb, and for your unaffected limb start doing the compounds, do flexion extension adduction abduction.

If you need surgery or anything like that, going into surgery with a leg that has been prehabbed is going to help your recovery since you're going to start with a strengthened leg that will then return to baseline as it recovers, instead of starting with a weak leg that then atrophies to below baseline and requires an extra month or two of therapy to build to baseline.

>>69471505
Good news, its just the meniscus so it's not a terribly expensive or long operation if you need it compared to having a ligament blown apart. Bad news, meniscus tears depending on the type are worse overall than just a ligament injury

If you opt for surgery, the biggest thing, and i mean the BIGGEST thing that will help you is preop PT. Kneesovertoes guy, post op PT, whatever, nothing will save you more time and pain than getting your knee mobility and quad/hamstring connection/strength up. Dont do anything stupid to injure your knee further. But go to a good PT and ask for a pre op PT program for knee injuries. Will save you months of rehab

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Post a picture of a goal body for you so we can tell you a more realistic answer.
Calisthenics will give you a spider type physique, which is to say big torso and small limbs. You can get a big chest, a big back and visible abs but your arms and legs will not be nearly as impressive as those body parts.
Legs won’t grow much because they’re much bigger muscles so they need more stimulus than your upper body. For example, benching 225 pounds is a very impressive lift. Deadlifting 225 is something most men will be able to do on the first day of the gym unless they have a bad injury.
Arms won’t grow much because you can’t really isolate them well. For triceps the best you can really do is diamond pushups which still incorporate chest a fair amount. For biceps, the best you can do is chinups, which are mostly a back exercise.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69471020
Yeah I think you could achieve a physique like this without gym. You will want to make the exercises more difficult once you can do more 20 reps in one set though. You can do this by adding some weight. You can just get a backpack and put rocks in it to do so.
IDK what kinda shape you’re in right now exactly but a good simple workout to start with would probably be
5 sets of as many pushups as possible
5 sets of as many chinups as possible
5 sets of as many sit-ups as possible
5 sets of as many squats as possible [you will probably need to use weight on the squats from the get go, maybe the situps too depending on what kinda shape you’re in]
Do this 3-4 times per week.
It’s important to remember that the vast majority of gains come from the last few reps in each set. They are the hardest reps and cause the most muscle damage.

>>69471310
It's faster to gain muscle and strength on a bulk
>( to achieve maintaining proper energy+losing fat+gaining muscle simultaneously?)
body recomp is a very slow process, one can argue that the end results are the same as for bulking and cutting where you will hardly make any gains and even love muscle during the cutting phase. The pro for body recomp is that you stay fit all year round.

Since noob gains are a thing it's recommended for beginners to eat at a 300-500 kcal surplus since you will be building muscle faster during the first year and those extra calories will be put to use. As you mature as a lifter you should lower your surplus all the way down to maybe 100-200 kcal surplus a day as an advanced lifter because building new muscle has slowed down significantly. For an advanced lifter a body recomp is probably the better choice.

Ex climber here (well I'm going to return to it after I move back to the West)

>>69466210
Both climbers and lifters range across the autism spectrum. Some are very friendly and will help you out with whatever, others will come up to you, give you unsolicited advice, then act like you're an asshole if you don't follow it.

>>69465940
>If you're already fit there's a good chance your muscles are stronger than your tendons.
True. Take harder climbs slowly. Often V4s for boulders and above and 5.10+'s and above require lots of crimps and technique. It becomes very easy to overload your tendons. Let them adapt. If you feel a slight ache, DO NOT CLIMB. Climbing injuries are ridiculously easy to get and hard to manage, and the earlier you get them the worse you are since you fuck up your tendons.

Just take it slowly and ease into it. After about 6months, your fingers will be based enough to not die. After about a year-18 months, you can start hangboarding if you want.

>>69466461
The chances are low if you ease gently into the sport. Just climb easy routes and if your fingers ever ache, don't climb that day. It's very simple. I introduced one of my friends to climbing, he immediately did soemthing called hangboarding, which is how climbers who've trained for years strengthen their fingers, and he tried to do pullups on it. He couldn't play piano for 2 months after. As long as you don't do anything ridiculously stupid like that, you'll be fine.

Avoid crimps until you're more comfortable with the sport. Finger strength takes time to develop. After climbing for 6 months, your tendons will be strong enough for more crimpy climbing. After about 18 months, your fingers tendons will be ridiculously tough and able to handle most extreme climbs. But it takes time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69466461
The chance of finger injury can be managed by your style of climbing (open/closed crimp, three finger drag etc), your preference for climb type (slopers or small crimpy climbs), and by how smart you approach the intensity/volume of your climbing.
In my opinion it takes over a year for the connective tissue in the hands to start catching up. You need to take it easy.

I could only climb 1-2x a week for a while because of how much it would affect my hands, that was probably at 20% body fat.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69455665
Fiber and probiotic foods have become a big part of our diet. I would not assume that either would be sufficient to right things though - fiber may feed all bacteria, good and bad. Probitoics seem to be hit and miss. It seems like you're better off eating fermented foods or culturing your own yogurt with known strains. Adding additional bacteria in that way certainly can't hurt, but I don't think we know enough to determine if it would offset the issues.
As for "healthier", that depends. The healthiest thing would be to cut all sugary drinks out of your diet all together except as rare treats and at that point consume ones with sweeteners that won't disrupt gut microbiota. I just noticed that your first post mentioned your cravings. I would suggest to decrease the amount of sweetened drinks (including artificially) that you drink over time. As you drink less, the cravings will subside/be more manageable. You'll also find that things like yogurt, carrots, etc. taste more sweet themselves since you're not overloading yourself with sugar constantly

Happy New Year, /fit/
I'm a 33 year old oldfag and I've done my fair share of lifting and trolling over the years (started lifting at 20) and still, up to this day, many young men are misguided when it comes to lifting and being healthy. Seeing as january is here, I'll be dropping some general redpills so you newfags have it easier and don't have to commit too many mistakes in your lifting journey. I'll save you all the bullshit and get straight to the point.

General /fit/ redpills:
>Realize that becoming and staying /fit/ is a life-long journey. You will be lifting every 2-4 days (depending on recovery) for the rest of your life. Once you come to terms with this, life will become easier.
>Consistency is king. Building muscle and losing fat takes a long time. Stay consistent for long enough and you'll get results.
>Do not expect to see quick results. As a natty, 2 years is least amount of time needed to start to look like you lift (perfect routine+diet). For most wagie /fit/ normies it will take closer to 5 years.
>All diets come down to CICO. You can not escape the law of thermodynamics. There are some individuals who have hormonal disruption which prevents them from losing weight, but there's a 99% chance that you're not one of them.
>People grossly overestimate the amount of lean muscle mass they are packing and grossly underestimate the amount of fat they actually store.
>Lean/big/natty. Pick two.
>For 99% of /fit/izens, "making it" implies having a beach bod (ascended ottermode) at 10-12% bodyfat.
>You do not need to do "the big three" (squats, deadlift, bench press) to get big.
>A healthy, athletic male has a visible six pack. If you do not have visible abs, you are fat. Simple as.
>Life starts at 12% bodyfat.
>Cardio does not kill gains. You look “smaller” when cutting because of decreased glycogen storage in the muscles which leads to lesser water retention which makes the muscle smaller and your layer of fat becomes thinner, thus you lose your fatceps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Your body doesn’t start eating up your muscles unless you’re starving for a prolonged time. People grossly overestimate the amount of “lost muscle mass” because of the previous point.
>Compound exercises are not enough to hit your core/abs. Doing over 9000 crunches will not give you visible abs. Abdominal, like any other exercise, benefit from your typical 6-12 hypertrophy rep range. Hanging weighted (lateral) leg raises in said range is the best overall abdominal exercise. Abs start to appear at around 13-14% bodyfat.
>Cardio is king. Swimming>cycling>running in terms of fun/efficiency. One hour session per week at the very minimum. Waterproof mp3 player for swimming sessions, use hand paddles and flippers.
>You don't really need any supplements, you can easily get all you need from a well-planned diet. A multivitamin when cutting is a good idea.
>An adult human should not be eating 3 times a day.
>CICO keto OMAD with bulletproof coffee in the morning and fasted cardio is the most efficient way of losing fat. Keto is good for maintenance and having low bodyfat due to decreased water retention. Keto is not good for building muscle/bulking.
>Weighted calisthenics (weighted ring dips/bulgarian dips/pullups/towel chinups/hanging leg raises) in the 6-12 rep hypertrophy range with progressive overload is pretty much all you need to have a strong and muscular upper body.
>Most of fitness "influencers" are not natty.
>Do not follow a bodybuilders brosplit made for roiders with increased metabolism and recovery as a natty.
>Sleeping is essential since most of your fat loss/muscle building occurs during your sleep. By cutting your sleeping hours you are cutting your gains.
>The anabolic window is a meme. Digestion takes 6-8 hours and most of your muscle repair occurs during night when you sleep.

I'll be updating the list as time moves on. Keep lifting and stay natty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I blew a disc about 6 years ago and it never healed right. I was squatting 465lbs and deadlifting 405 before, and got close to those numbers a couple years after, but the back pain was always there, either a dull pain or sometimes like there was a screwdriver stuck into my spine. What finally has been working for me was stopping all lifting (maybe 1 workout of random dumbbell stuff a week, usually not) and getting into running, like 10-15 miles a week, and golfing. Just running and golfing for about 3 months or so. The past 3 or 4 months I've started lifting again, up to 3pl8 on bench, but I only squat 135 for 2x8, and deadlift 135 for 2x8 about once a week, as I'm too worried that I'll hurt my back again and get set back to square 1, constant back pain all day.

Once my back pain was mostly gone day to day, I'd still get it when I did cheerleading stunts, but adding in the light squats and deadlifts has really made it feel better and stronger. I'm doing some Jefferson curls with no weights now, like 3 or 4 reps once or twice a weeks and I think that's helped unlock my back again, since chronic pain tends to lock up any joint, back pain especially.

Also I stretch my glutes, which are pretty tight usually and a lot of the time that will help if my back starts to ache during the day. My favorite is the ankle on knee glute stretch, not sure of the name of it but you can google it.

Running I think is the main fix for me at least, I noticed the biggest change when I started to run instead of lift weights. Probably is something to do with the light repetitive twisting motion that happens when you run. If you have chronic back pain, I suggest getting in to running a bit. I started with just a mile, then did 1.25, then 1.5, and after about a month I was up to doing 2 or 2.5 miles at a time 3 or 4 times a week. I did not run at all for the 5 years I dealt with the back pain, and since I started, it's the biggest fix I've ever tried.

t. 21-26 year old with severe back pain

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
48kg down so far (116kg to 68kg)
Got morbidly obese from eating multiple blocks of chocolate, bags of lollies, 2litres of strawberry milk every day. I was a fat disgusting mess.
Started in 2019 just walking laps of the local oval. Could barely walk 3 laps before being exhausted.
2020 I didn't really make a heap of progress. The lockdowns completely fucked my head and I nearly an hero'd (fuck you Dan Andrews).
2021 I got a bit more serious about it. The weight was starting to come off. I found a free outdoor gym a few suburbs away so I made a habit of going there before work as often as I could. This worked well, there was an elliptical and some equipment for doing arms (I'm retarded, don't know the names) and a small field. I was doing 1hr on the elliptical, a little bit of arms, then was attempting some jogging in the field. Although I could barely jog for more than 7 mins I could feel how good it was for my body.
Later in 2021 my knee got fucked up from using the shitty elliptical too often. I couldn't put any pressure on my knee for about 2 months, could barely walk, so this put a stop on things for a while.
Once my knee was better I got covid and was sick as fuck for a month.
2022 came around and I wanted to push everything to another level. I got myself a football and was doing as much cardio as I could manage. I got a diary to keep track of everything - this was a gamechanger. When I could see my progress written down it pushed me even harder.
Mid 2022 I started running seriously. 10km per day. Eventually my knees decided that was a bad idea and I knocked it down to 8km 5days per week which seems a lot less taxing on the joints. I've also got into doing some long bike rides.
My current routine is 8km run 5 days per week. 40km bike ride 4 days per week. 35 mins of simple dumbbell work/curls.
2023 I'm 68kg and kicking arse at my fitness goals. Ive got a lot of loose skin which I am filling with muscle. Things are looking good. Still can't get a root though.
